Authors: Yu Ping Liang, Chao jung Wu, Hui Wen Tsai, Hui Fang Ni
Title:
Characterization and pathogenicity of Lasiodiplodia species
associated with avocado branch canker in Taiwan
Keywords:
Avocado, Branch canker, Lasiodiplodia theobromae,
Lasiodiplodia pseudotheobromae, Taiwan
Abstract:
Avocado branch cankers had been reported from many
avocado-growing countries, and were associated with several species in
the Botryosphaeriaceae family. In Taiwan, the disease is widely
distributed in main avocado-producing regions. Therefore, the aims of
this study were to identify and characterize the pathogens associated
with avocado branch canker in Taiwan, and evaluate their pathogenicity.
Thirteen fungal isolates were obtained from necrotic avocado woody
tissues from 7 orchards located in different regions in Taiwan. Based on
morphology and phylogenetic analyses of internal transcribed spacer
(ITS) sequence and partial sequences of the translation elongation
factor 1-α (TEF1-α) and beta-tubulin (Bt) gene, the isolates were
identified as either Lasiodiplodia theobromae or L. pseudotheobromae.
The optimal temperature of mycelial growth for both species was around
30°C. Pathogenicity tests conducted on ‘Hall’ avocado plants showed that
both species were pathogenic to avocado, causing whitish exudate at the
inoculation sites and necrosis on the stem 4 weeks after inoculation.
This study identified and characterized the pathogens of avocado branch
canker in Taiwan, which will provide useful information to future
research on establishing effective disease management strategies in
avocado. To our knowledge, this is the first report characterizing
avocado branch canker in Taiwan.
